title: Fluidity in the Medieval Aristotle. Readers and Readings of the Greek-Latin Translations
descriptions:
Title: Unveiling the Medieval Reception of Aristotle: A Critical Edition of Latin Translations

Abstract:

The profound impact of Aristotle's works on medieval philosophy, science, and theology is underscored by the numerous surviving manuscripts from the late medieval and early modern periods. However, the process of transmission and interpretation of his ideas through Latin translations remains understudied. This gap is largely attributed to the oversight of modifications and annotations found in handwritten manuscripts, which hold the key to understanding the medieval reception of Aristotle's thought. This project seeks to address this knowledge gap by producing cutting-edge critical editions of Latin translations of three pivotal Aristotelian treatises on natural philosophy: De anima, De generatione et corruptione, and De caelo. By examining the textual variance across manuscript witnesses, this study aims to illuminate the complex dynamics of how medieval readers engaged with and interpreted the translations, which differed significantly from their Greek counterparts. The project's innovative approach will not only shed light on the significance of textual fluidity in the manuscripts but also develop a novel model of interpretation applicable to other medieval translations of philosophy and science, thus advancing our understanding of the medieval intellectual landscape.

**Description:**

Aristotle’s impact on philosophy, science, and theology has been overwhelming, especially in the late medieval and early modern periods: hundreds of Aristotelian manuscripts survive to attest how strongly his works belong to the written culture of the pre-modern intellectual world. The understanding of Aristotle’s thought was decisively shaped by Latin translations from the 12th and 13th centuries. Translators’ efforts to preserve the exact phrasing of the texts and readers’ struggles to determine the disturbingly novel meaning lie hidden in modifications and notes in the manuscripts. These have however not received the attention they deserve, leading to a significant gap in our knowledge of the medieval reception of Aristotle. FitMA aims to fill this gap through a comprehensive investigation into the new ways to read the Latin Aristotle, with a ground-breaking focus on the textual variance in the handwritten books that preserve the translations. To realize that goal, FitMA will produce state-of-the-art critical editions of Greek-Latin translations of three of Aristotle’s most influential treatises on natural philosophy: De anima, De generatione et corruptione, and De caelo. Critical editions are the established scholarly means to document the variant readings in all manuscript witnesses of an ancient or medieval text. The study of that variance across versions or textual fluidity provides first-hand evidence how readers were exposed to the recently available translations, which are fundamentally different from their Greek originals. Because every manuscript copy of the Latin Aristotle generates a different state for its medieval reception, which cannot be adequately studied from the Greek text or a modern translation, FitMA will advance the state of the art by uncovering the importance of textual fluidity in the manuscripts of these translations and developing an innovative model of interpretation applicable to other medieval translations of philosophy and science.
